questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high fever, chills, and headache after returning from a trip to a malaria-endemic region. On examination, he appears pale and febrile. His travel history raises suspicion of malaria. What is the most sensitive diagnostic test for identifying the species of malaria parasite in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Thin smear with Acridine orange stain

questions.correct_answer: B. Thin smear with Acridine orange stain
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thin smear with Acridine orange stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acridine orange-stained thin smears are highly sensitive and rapid for detecting malaria parasites and are close to 100% in sensitivity and specificity. Although Giemsa stain remains the global gold standard, Acridine orange is often preferred in emergency settings for its quick results.
  • ➤ Acridine orange-stained thin smears are highly sensitive and rapid for detecting malaria parasites and are close to 100% in sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of high fever, abdominal pain, and bleeding gums. She has petechiae on her extremities, and her platelet count is significantly reduced. The clinical presentation raises suspicion of Dengue Hemorrhagic Syndrome. What is the most definitive diagnostic test for dengue infection at this stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients presenting within the first 7 days of dengue symptoms, RT-PCR is the most definitive diagnostic test, as it detects dengue virus RNA during the acute phase of infection.
  • ➤ RT-PCR

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a 3-day history of diarrhea and decreased oral intake. On examination, the child is restless, has sunken eyes, and the skin pinch goes back slowly. According to the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, which category of dehydration does this child fall into?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Some dehydration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the IMNCI framework, a child with diarrhea is classified as having Some Dehydration if they exhibit at least two of the following signs: restlessness or irritability, sunken eyes, and a skin pinch that goes back slowly.
  • ➤ Some Dehydration

questions.text: A 27-year-old medical student is analyzing the systolic blood pressure readings of 100 patients as part of a research project. After calculating the mean systolic blood pressure, he uses the following formula for further calculation: What statistical measure is the student calculating?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Standard deviation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Standard deviation is the most commonly used measure of dispersion. It quantifies the amount of variation or spread in a set of data values. It is calculated as the square root of the variance, and understanding this formula is critical for interpreting data variability.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is part of a clinical study evaluating the performance of two screening tests for colorectal cancer: Test A (a new biomarker assay) and Test B (a standard fecal occult blood test). A total of 200 patients participate in the study, with the following results: Based on the above data, what is the kappa statistic for the agreement between Test A and Test B?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 0.4

questions.text: Match the following vectors with the diseases they transmit:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Housefly → B. Yaws Sandfly → A. Oroya fever Tse-Tse Fly → C. Sleeping sickness Blackfly → D.Onchocerciasis
  • ➤ Housefly → B. Yaws
  • ➤ Sandfly → A. Oroya fever
  • ➤ Tse-Tse Fly → C. Sleeping sickness
  • ➤ Blackfly → D.Onchocerciasis

questions.text: What is the name of the approach shown in the image, which uses hidden phone numbers to monitor medication adherence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 99DOTS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 99DOTS utilizes hidden phone numbers for medication adherence monitoring, achieving up to 99% cure rates for those who adhere properly.
  • ➤ 99DOTS

questions.text: All of the following are targets set by the National Health Policy 2017 to be achieved by 2025, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction of premature mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases by 30%

options.label: B
options.text: Neonatal mortality rate (NNMR) of 16 per 1000 live births

options.label: C
options.text: Increase life expectancy at birth to 70 years

options.label: D
options.text: Achieve a TB cure rate greater than 85% and target TB elimination

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduction of premature mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases by 30%
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reduction of premature mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases by 30%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific targets of the National Health Policy 2017 for 2025, such as reducing NNMR to 16, increasing life expectancy to 70 years, and achieving an 85% TB cure rate. Remember that the policy aims to reduce premature mortality from NCDs by 25% , not 30%.
  • ➤ National Health Policy 2017
  • ➤ 25%

questions.text: A 50-year-old hospital administrator is reviewing the bed utilization rates in a 300-bed hospital. The administrator notices that some beds remain unoccupied for extended periods after patient discharge, while others are immediately filled. He understands that for the most efficient use of hospital resources, there should be a short waiting period before a new patient is admitted after a discharge. What should the bed turnover interval ideally be to indicate optimum utilization of hospital services?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Slightly positive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An efficient hospital should maintain a slightly positive bed turnover interval, which ensures a smooth transition between patient discharges and admissions, preventing bed shortages and resource wastage. This balance is crucial for effective hospital resource management.

questions.text: A global health researcher is tasked with comparing the vital statistics, particularly mortality rates, across different countries with varying age distributions. To ensure that the comparison accurately reflects the differences in mortality, which of the following measures is most appropriate for the comparison?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Age standardized death rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The age-standardized death rate is the most appropriate measure for comparing mortality across populations with different age distributions, as it adjusts for demographic differences and allows for fair and meaningful comparisons.
  • ➤ age-standardized death rate

questions.text: Primary level of prevention includes? Screening of disease Quarantine Isolation Diagnosis Vaccination
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ primary prevention strategies include actions taken to prevent the onset of disease, such as vaccination and quarantine , aimed at protecting public health by stopping the spread of infections before they can take hold in the community.
  • ➤ primary prevention
  • ➤ vaccination and quarantine

questions.text: Match the following research institutes with their corresponding locations: National JALMA Institute for Leprosy National Institute of Occupational Health (NIOH) National Institute of Epidemiology National AIDS Research Institute (NARI) Options: Pune Ahmedabad Agra Chennai
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) a-3, b-2, c-4, d-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ a3: National JALMA Institute for Leprosy – Agra b2: National Institute of Occupational Health – Ahmedabad c4: National Institute of Epidemiology – Chennai d1: National AIDS Research Institute – Pune
  • ➤ a3: National JALMA Institute for Leprosy – Agra
  • ➤ a3:
  • ➤ b2: National Institute of Occupational Health – Ahmedabad
  • ➤ b2:
  • ➤ c4: National Institute of Epidemiology – Chennai
  • ➤ c4:
  • ➤ d1: National AIDS Research Institute – Pune
  • ➤ d1:

questions.text: A 35-year-old epidemiologist is investigating the pattern of a specific infectious disease over a 10-year period in a community. She notices that the incidence of the disease increases and decreases in a regular cycle every few years. Which of the following best explains this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cyclical trend

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cyclical trend describes a regular pattern of increases and decreases in disease incidence occurring over several years, influenced by factors such as population immunity and pathogen variation. This concept is important for predicting disease outbreaks and planning public health interventions.
  • ➤ cyclical trend

questions.text: A 50-year-old public health specialist is developing a prevention program to reduce disease incidence in a community. She evaluates different measures aimed at specific protection and realizes that not all interventions target the prevention of disease in a population. Which of the following interventions is not considered a method of specific protection?

options.label: A
options.text: Pap smear for early detection of carcinoma cervix in the community

options.label: C
options.text: Wearing of seat belts by car drivers

questions.correct_answer: A. Pap smear for early detection of carcinoma cervix in the community
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pap smear for early detection of carcinoma cervix in the community

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Specific protection refers to primary prevention measures aimed at protecting against the onset of disease or injury. Screening tests like the Pap smear are part of secondary prevention , as they aim to detect diseases early rather than prevent their occurrence.
  • ➤ Specific protection
  • ➤ secondary prevention

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with no prior history of heart disease visits his physician for a routine check-up. The patient is concerned about heart disease, as many of his family members have been diagnosed with hypertension. The physician discusses various preventive strategies to address risk factors at the population level and prevent the development of risk factors themselves. Which of the following strategies is an example of primordial prevention for coronary heart disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Salt restriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primordial prevention targets risk factors at a population level before they develop, while primary prevention focuses on managing existing risk factors to prevent disease onset. Salt restriction is a classic example of primordial prevention in the context of preventing coronary heart disease.
  • ➤ Primordial prevention

questions.text: First step and Last step in planning cycle include:

options.label: A
options.text: Analysis of existing health situation, Implementation

options.label: C
options.text: Analysis of existing health situation, Evaluation

questions.correct_answer: C. Analysis of existing health situation, Evaluation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Analysis if existing health situation, Evaluation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The planning cycle starts with the analysis of the existing situation to identify the needs and resources available and concludes with an evaluation to measure the effectiveness of the implemented strategies.

questions.text: A public health researcher is investigating a newly emerging disease with no clear etiological hypothesis. The researcher aims to collect all the possible information about the disease. Which of the following study designs is the best initial choice for assessing this unknown disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Descriptive epidemiology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Descriptive epidemiology is used to gather and describe the characteristics of an emerging disease when no hypothesis is present. It helps in understanding the distribution of disease and forming an initial hypothesis based on person, place, and time factors.

questions.text: A community of 750,000 people had 150 deaths in a year. Out of those 150 deaths, 25 individuals died due to pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). What is the proportional mortality rate from TB in this population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 16.7%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The proportional mortality rate (PMR) is a measure of the proportion of deaths caused by a specific disease out of the total deaths from all causes, expressed as a percentage. It helps in understanding the relative impact of a particular cause of death within a community.

questions.text: A public health officer is tasked with assessing the burden of diabetes in a population of 8,000 people. There are 400 newly diagnosed cases of diabetes this year, along with 600 previously known cases. What is the prevalence of diabetes in this population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 12.5%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prevalence is a measure of the total burden of a disease in a population, encompassing both new and existing cases. It is calculated as a proportion and expressed as a percentage when multiplied by 100. Understanding this concept is crucial for assessing and comparing disease burdens across different populations.

questions.text: A physician at a community health center has observed a significant rise in reported fever cases over the past week. Typically, the center registers between 20-30 cases of fever each week. This week, however, the number has unexpectedly escalated to 128 cases. Based on this information, which term most accurately describes the sudden increase in disease incidence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epidemic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The terminology used to describe the patterns of disease occurrence:
  • ➤ Epidemic: A sudden increase in cases above normal expectancy in a defined area. Sporadic: Irregular and infrequent cases. Endemic: Continuous presence of a disease in a specific area. Pandemic: An epidemic that spreads across international borders, affecting large populations globally.
  • ➤ Epidemic: A sudden increase in cases above normal expectancy in a defined area.
  • ➤ Epidemic:
  • ➤ Sporadic: Irregular and infrequent cases.
  • ➤ Sporadic:
  • ➤ Endemic: Continuous presence of a disease in a specific area.
  • ➤ Endemic:
  • ➤ Pandemic: An epidemic that spreads across international borders, affecting large populations globally.
  • ➤ Pandemic:

questions.text: In a recent public health study, researchers determined that the attributable risk percentage of developing lung cancer due to smoking among smokers is 90%. This statistic reflects the proportion of lung cancer cases in smokers that could be prevented if smoking were eliminated. With this information, which statement accurately describes the impact of smoking on lung cancer incidence among smokers?

options.label: A
options.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

options.label: B
options.text: 90% of lung cancer cases can be eliminated in the population if smoking is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: 90% of lung cancer cases can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: 10% of lung cancer cases can be eliminated in the population if smoking is eliminated

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Attributable risk percentage specifies the proportion of disease cases in an exposed group that can be directly linked to a risk factor. In this case, 90% of lung cancer cases in smokers are due to smoking, and 10% are due to other causes. It is important to distinguish between individual-level (attributable risk) and population-level (population attributable risk) statistics.

questions.text: A group of epidemiologists is reviewing data from previous health studies to assess the effects of environmental exposures on long-term health outcomes. As they delve into the methodologies used, they discuss the distinctive aspects of retrospective cohort studies. One feature mentioned does not align with the typical attributes of this type of study. Which of the following does not accurately describe retrospective cohort studies?

options.label: A
options.text: The study groups are exposed and non-exposed

options.label: C
options.text: The required sample size is smaller than that needed for a concurrent cohort study

questions.correct_answer: C. The required sample size is smaller than that needed for a concurrent cohort study
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The required sample size is smaller than that needed for a concurrent cohort study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retrospective cohort studies use past records to identify exposure status but maintain a forward direction to assess the incidence of outcomes. The sample size requirements are not inherently smaller than those of prospective cohort studies; they depend on study-specific statistical considerations.

questions.text: In a study examining the relationship between sun exposure and skin cancer, researchers notice that individuals with fair skin have a higher incidence of skin cancer and also tend to avoid the sun more than those with darker skin tones. This variable skin tone is a confounding factor and potentially skewing the study's results. Which statement correctly defines a characteristic of a confounding factor?

options.label: A
options.text: It is found equally between the study and the control groups

options.label: B
options.text: It is itself a risk factor for the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Confounding can be eliminated by selecting a small group

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated either with the exposure or the disease

questions.correct_answer: B. It is itself a risk factor for the disease
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A confounding factor is a variable that is independently a risk factor for the disease and is associated with the exposure of interest. Proper study design or statistical methods are required to control for confounding to accurately assess the relationship between an exposure and an outcome.

questions.text: In a research project focused on assessing the impact of air pollution levels on respiratory health, investigators collect data from different urban areas to compare the incidence of asthma among residents exposed to varying levels of pollutants. The objective is to evaluate how strongly the exposure to pollutants is linked to asthma outcomes. Which statistical measure is most appropriate for assessing the strength of association between the exposure (air pollution) and the health outcome (asthma)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Relative risk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relative Risk is the preferred statistical measure for evaluating the strength of association between an exposure and an outcome in cohort studies. It provides a clear comparison of the risk between different exposure levels, helping to assess how strongly exposure is linked to the health outcome.
  • ➤ Relative Risk

questions.text: In the field of epidemiology, determining causal relationships between potential risk factors and disease outcomes is crucial for understanding disease etiology. One of the key criteria used to establish such a relationship is notoriously challenging to prove, often due to the complex interplay of various biological, environmental, and genetic factors. Which of the following is considered the most difficult criterion to establish when assessing the causal association in the etiology of a disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Specificity of association

Explanation:

  • • Temporality Definition : Temporality means that the cause precedes the effect. In other words, the exposure must occur before the onset of the disease. Importance : This is the most critical and necessary criterion for establishing causality. Best Study Design : A cohort study is the best design to establish temporality because it follows subjects over time from exposure to outcome.
  • • Temporality
  • • Definition : Temporality means that the cause precedes the effect. In other words, the exposure must occur before the onset of the disease. Importance : This is the most critical and necessary criterion for establishing causality. Best Study Design : A cohort study is the best design to establish temporality because it follows subjects over time from exposure to outcome.

A strong association provides greater evidence for a causal relationship. Measurements : Relative Risk (RR) : Used in cohort studies. Odds Ratio (OR) : Used in case-control studies. Relevance : A stronger association (high RR or OR) provides more confidence in a causal link.

Measurements : Relative Risk (RR) : Used in cohort studies. Odds Ratio (OR) : Used in case-control studies. However, this criterion is difficult to establish because many diseases have multifactorial causes. Explanation : Modern diseases often involve multiple causes, making it nearly impossible to attribute a disease solely to one factor (e.g., coronary heart disease has multiple risk factors like smoking, diet, genetics).

  • • Consistency of Association Definition : This criterion states that the results should be consistent and replicable across different studies and populations. Explanation : If several studies conducted in different settings yield similar findings, the association is considered more reliable.

Example : If smoking increases in females and studies also show an increase in lung cancer in females, this coherence supports causality.

  • • Dose-Response Relationship Definition : As the dose of the exposure increases, the risk of the disease should also increase. Example : The more cigarettes a person smokes per day, the higher the risk of developing lung cancer.
  • • Dose-Response Relationship
  • • Definition : As the dose of the exposure increases, the risk of the disease should also increase. Example : The more cigarettes a person smokes per day, the higher the risk of developing lung cancer.

  • ➤ Specificity of association is the most difficult criterion to establish in Hill’s criteria of causality. This is because most diseases are influenced by multiple factors rather than a single, exclusive cause, making it challenging to link a disease specifically to one risk factor. Understanding the multifactorial nature of diseases is essential in epidemiological research.

questions.text: A medical team is conducting a training session on the management of exposure to infectious diseases, emphasizing the importance of timely intervention to prevent disease onset. They discuss various diseases for which post-exposure vaccination is crucial. One of the diseases mentioned requires immediate vaccination after exposure to prevent severe outcomes. Which disease, when exposed to, necessitates post-exposure vaccination as a preventive measure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies is a disease requiring immediate post-exposure vaccination to prevent nearly inevitable fatality. Rabies is unique in its high case fatality rate and the critical need for timely vaccination and possible immunoglobulin administration to be effective. Understanding this distinction can be crucial for emergency medical management.
  • ➤ Rabies

questions.text: In a discussion among epidemiologists, the topic of accurately determining the incubation period of diseases arises. The incubation period is critical for understanding the dynamics of disease transmission and implementing control measures. Various proxy measures are often used to estimate this period. However, one of the listed measures is not typically used to estimate the incubation period. Identify which of the following is not a proxy measure used for estimating the incubation period in disease epidemiology.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Period of communicability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Period of Communicability is not a proxy measure for estimating the incubation period. The incubation period and the period of communicability have different implications in the context of disease transmission and control. Understanding these terms and their roles in epidemiology is vital for disease prevention and management.
  • ➤ Period of Communicability

questions.text: During a public health briefing about a suspected surge in infectious disease cases in a regional community, health authorities outline the initial steps required to accurately investigate the situation. Among the listed steps, which is the initial-most action required in the investigation of an epidemic?

options.label: B
options.text: Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid search for all cases and their characteristics

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Verification of diagnosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial-most action in an epidemic investigation is the verification of diagnosis . This step is crucial to ensure that the disease in question is correctly identified, preventing unnecessary panic and enabling appropriate public health responses. The sequence of steps must be logical and systematic to manage and contain disease outbreaks effectively.
  • ➤ initial-most action in an epidemic investigation is the verification of diagnosis

questions.text: Efficacy rates play a crucial role in disease control efforts by indicating how effective a vaccine is at preventing the disease in the vaccinated population under optimal conditions. Among the vaccines listed below, which is known to have the highest efficacy rate when administered according to the recommended schedule?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The measles vaccine has one of the highest efficacy rates among vaccines when given in the recommended two-dose schedule, providing up to 99% protection. Understanding vaccine efficacy is crucial for implementing effective disease prevention strategies and achieving high levels of immunity in populations.
  • ➤ measles vaccine

questions.text: In a laboratory setting where strict sterilization protocols are necessary to prevent contamination, different methods are used to sterilize various materials. Which is the best method recommended for TB sputum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Incineration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incineration is the most effective method for sterilizing TB sputum to ensure the complete destruction of infectious pathogens. Proper disposal and sterilization are critical in controlling the spread of tuberculosis, especially during the initial infective period. Additionally, they should understand the importance of using alternative methods like dry burning when incineration is not feasible.
  • ➤ Incineration is the most effective method for sterilizing TB sputum

questions.text: In a strategic meeting focusing on improving vaccine distribution logistics, state health officials review potential weak points in maintaining the cold chain—a critical system for keeping vaccines at required temperatures throughout their journey from manufacturer to administration. Where is the risk of cold chain failure deemed highest among the levels of healthcare delivery discussed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subcentre & village level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Subcentre & village level poses the greatest risk for cold chain failure due to inadequate monitoring and reliance on simpler vaccine carriers during transportation. Maintaining vaccine efficacy is crucial, especially in rural and remote areas, to ensure successful immunization efforts.
  • ➤ Subcentre & village level

questions.text: In efforts to combat infectious diseases in regions prone to specific outbreaks, several vaccines, such as Dukoral, Shanchol, and mORCVAX, have been developed. These vaccines are tailored for a particular disease, helping to prevent outbreaks and control spread in vulnerable populations. Identify the disease these vaccines target based on their names.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholera

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dukoral, Shanchol, and mORCVAX are cholera vaccines . Recognizing vaccine names and their target diseases is important for understanding disease prevention strategies, especially in areas prone to outbreaks of waterborne diseases like cholera.
  • ➤ Dukoral, Shanchol, and mORCVAX are cholera vaccines

questions.text: A patient who has been experiencing recurrent Trichomoniasis infections consults her healthcare provider about her upcoming Pap smear test, expressing curiosity about its purpose. Given the need for clarity in understanding the role of this procedure in women's health care, what is the most accurate description of a Pap smear?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a screening test for cervical cancer

options.label: B
options.text: It's a diagnostic test for cervical cancer

options.label: C
options.text: It's a screening for cancer of the female genital tract

options.label: D
options.text: It's a diagnostic test for Trichomoniasis infection

questions.correct_answer: A. It's a screening test for cervical cancer

questions.text: A healthcare professional is explaining to a colleague the characteristics of diagnostic tests, particularly focusing on a test's ability to correctly identify those who do not have a disease when they are indeed disease-free. questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Specificity measures a test's ability to correctly exclude a disease in those who are disease-free. This metric is crucial for reducing unnecessary diagnostic procedures and treatments. Understanding specificity and how it contrasts with sensitivity is essential for evaluating and interpreting diagnostic tests in clinical practice.
  • ➤ Specificity

questions.text: A healthcare policy maker is outlining different types of screening programs that are utilized within the public health system to detect diseases or medical conditions. Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

questions.text: During a community health initiative aimed at promoting breast cancer awareness, healthcare professionals educate women on the proper timing for performing breast self-examinations (BSE). questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

questions.text: Denominator of PPV is?

questions.text: True about breast feeding is? Energy content is 65 Kcal/100ml IgA is in highest quantity Linoleic acid exclusivity helps in brain development Start at delivery table itself Iron content is high but absorption is low

questions.text: Which of the following strains are used for production of viral vaccines? Ty21a Jeryll Lynn 17D RA 27/3 RTS, S (AS01) NIV-2020-770

questions.text: During a training session for healthcare professionals about the specifics of vaccines used against bacterial infections, the discussion turns to the meningococcal vaccine. questions.explanation:

questions.text: During a healthcare policy review meeting focusing on the historical reduction in tuberculosis (TB) cases, the contributions of various factors are discussed. questions.explanation:

questions.text: During a medical conference focused on advances in diagnostics for infectious diseases, the effectiveness of the Xpert MTB/RIF test is discussed. This rapid molecular test is highlighted for its ability to both detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis (the bacteria causing tuberculosis) and assess resistance to certain antibiotics. options.label: D

questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a history of sudden onset vomiting, occurring 3-4 hours after consuming a meal. Based on the timing and nature of the symptoms, the healthcare team considers various foodborne pathogens that could be responsible for this acute gastroenteritis. Which organism is the most likely cause of these symptoms given the rapid onset after eating?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning presents with rapid onset of symptoms, usually vomiting, within 1 to 6 hours of consuming contaminated food. Recognize the key differences in incubation periods and symptomatology between common foodborne pathogens to make accurate clinical assessments.
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus
  • ➤ Additional Note:
  • ➤ Additional Note:
  • ➤ Another organism with a similar rapid onset of symptoms (1 to 6 hours) is Bacillus cereus , specifically the emetic type , which is associated with vomiting. However, Staphylococcus aureus remains the most likely answer given the classic association with rapid-onset vomiting.
  • ➤ Bacillus cereus
  • ➤ emetic type

questions.text: False regarding WHO Low Osmolarity ORS is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Citrate 20 mmol/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ WHO Low Osmolarity ORS
  • ➤ ReSoMal
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnourished) : This is specifically designed for severely malnourished children, as they require a different electrolyte balance. In ReSoMal, the sodium concentration is lower (45 mmol/L), and potassium concentration is higher (40 mmol/L) compared to standard WHO ORS. This adjustment is necessary because malnourished children are more susceptible to sodium overload and often have higher potassium losses.
  • ➤ ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnourished)

questions.text: During a public health evaluation focused on malaria transmission in a community, health officials need to identify the most sensitive index for detecting recent malaria transmission. questions.text: Recently, a child who had completed a full rabies vaccination course in December 2023 presents with an oozing wound on their great toe after being scratched by a pet that has also been vaccinated against rabies. questions.text: In a public health briefing on emerging infectious diseases, the focus shifts to monkeypox, a viral zoonosis with symptoms similar to those seen in smallpox patients, although clinically less severe. What is the route of transmission for the monkeypox virus?

questions.text: As part of the planning for public health messaging and events surrounding World AIDS Day 2024, organizers are integrating the chosen theme into all activities. questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6-12

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Amid recent health alerts, public health officials in India are closely monitoring the situation following confirmed reports of a viral hemorrhagic fever affecting several communities. Viral hemorrhagic fevers are a group of illnesses caused by four distinct families of viruses. Some of these diseases can be highly contagious and deadly, leading to severe outbreaks. Which viral hemorrhagic fever has recently been confirmed as outbreaks of clinical cases within India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chandipura virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Chandipura virus, transmitted by Phlebotomus sandflies, has been linked to outbreaks in India, notably in Gujarat. Additionally, they should note that Aedes aegypti has been identified as a potential, although less common, vector for this virus.

questions.text: During a longitudinal study on cardiovascular health, researchers focus on the phenomenon known as "tracking" of blood pressure (BP) to assess its implications for long-term health outcomes. "Tracking" refers to the stability or predictability of blood pressure levels over an individual's lifetime. What does the term "tracking of BP" typically imply?
questions.correct_answer: D. BP of hypotensive remain hypotensive
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) BP of hypotensive remain hypotensive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The term "tracking" of blood pressure refers to the stability of an individual's BP level relative to their peers over time. Specifically, individuals who are hypotensive are likely to remain hypotensive, and those who are hypertensive are likely to remain hypertensive throughout their lifetime.

questions.text: In a study focusing on ocular health across various regions in India, researchers aim to identify the leading causes of eye-related diseases and conditions that significantly impair quality of life. Understanding the most prevalent ocular morbidity can guide public health interventions and resource allocation. What is recognized as the most common cause of ocular morbidity in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Refraction error

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refractive error is the most common cause of ocular morbidity in India, whereas cataract is the leading cause of blindness, low vision, and severe visual impairment. Understanding these distinctions is crucial for public health planning and the allocation of resources for eye care services.

questions.text: A 42-year-old software developer attends a health screening event organized by his employer. The healthcare professional calculates his Body Mass Index (BMI) to evaluate his risk for conditions associated with overweight and obesity. What is the calculated BMI for this individual?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 31

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following groups is not eligible to receive benefits under the SUMAN scheme?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sick children

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The SUMAN scheme focuses on reducing maternal and neonatal mortality by providing healthcare services to pregnant women, mothers up to 6 months postpartum, and newborns. Sick children (beyond the neonatal period) are not covered under this scheme.

questions.text: As part of the Malaria Eradication Programme in India, one of the primary strategies involves the use of insecticides. This method targets the vector directly by aiming to significantly reduce the lifespan of mosquitoes, thereby interrupting the transmission cycle of malaria. What is the targeted lifespan reduction for mosquitoes under this strategy, to effectively reduce malaria transmission?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Less than 10 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reducing the lifespan of Anopheles mosquitoes to less than 10 days is a key strategy in interrupting malaria transmission. This is because the malaria parasite requires about 10-14 days to become infectious within the mosquito.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to a primary health care (PHC) facility with symptoms of fever and cough. Upon examination, the child displays chest in-drawing and has a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute. His weight is recorded at 11 kg. options.label: C

options.label: D

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to IMNCI guidelines, children with chest in-drawing and signs of pneumonia should be treated with antibiotics and followed up in 3 days. Referral is necessary only if the disease is classified as severe or very severe.

questions.text: During a national conference on tuberculosis (TB) management, a session highlights the Nikshay Poshan Yojana, a government initiative aimed at supporting TB patients in India. questions.text: A drug which reduces mortality but does not cure a disease, will gradually lead to:
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A woman who has four daughters presents for a routine prenatal check at 18 weeks of pregnancy. This is her fifth pregnancy, and she is receiving an ultrasound as part of her standard antenatal care. Given the context of India's regulations aimed at preventing gender-based discrimination before birth, such as the PCPNDT Act which prohibits prenatal sex determination, how should the ultrasound procedure be conducted?

options.label: A
options.text: Refrain from conducting the ultrasound scan.

options.label: B
options.text: Perform the ultrasound but avoid determining or revealing the fetus's gender.

options.label: C
options.text: Determine the fetus's gender but keep the information confidential and not disclose it to the woman.

options.label: D
options.text: Determine and disclose the fetus's gender to the woman.

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform the ultrasound but avoid determining or revealing the fetus's gender.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perform the ultrasound but avoid determining or revealing the fetus's gender.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under the PCPNDT Act, routine ultrasounds for prenatal care are allowed, but determining and revealing the gender of the fetus is strictly prohibited to prevent gender-based discrimination. The ultrasound must be performed solely for medical reasons without disclosing any information about the fetus's gender.

questions.text: A 22-week pregnant woman, whose pregnancy resulted from rape, seeks advice regarding the possibility of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).   • ➤ The life-threatening complication associated with the use of the "Today" sponge is toxic shock syndrome (TSS) . This rare but serious condition can occur when bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, produce toxins that enter the bloodstream.
  • ➤ toxic shock syndrome (TSS)

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman visits a primary health care antenatal clinic and is found to have a hemoglobin level of 9 gm/dl. Considering her anemia, the healthcare provider needs to decide when to start her on iron folic acid supplementation. What is the most appropriate time to begin this supplementation during her pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediately

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron and folic acid supplementation is started immediately in pregnant women who are found to have anemia. Routine supplementation for all pregnant women begins in the second trimester, but cases of identified anemia require earlier and more aggressive management to prevent adverse maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female with 18 months baby on breast feed has heavy irregular bleeding on mensuration. What is best contraception advisable?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Progestasert

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Progesterone-only contraceptives, such as Progestasert or progesterone-only pills, are the preferred choice for breastfeeding women. These options are safe, do not affect lactation, and can be beneficial for managing menstrual irregularities. Additionally, estrogen-containing contraceptives should be avoided in lactating mothers.

questions.text: What is the name of this syringe technology discovered by Marc Koska?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) K1 auto-disable syringe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The importance of the K1 auto-disable syringe in preventing the spread of blood-borne infections through safe injection practices. This technology ensures that syringes cannot be reused, significantly contributing to public health safety.
  • ➤ K1 auto-disable syringe

questions.text: Identifying the first application of KAP studies in India provides insight into the public health priorities at the time. What was the first health issue addressed by KAP studies in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Family planning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Family planning was the first health issue addressed by KAP studies in India. These studies were used to inform and guide public health strategies, particularly in areas related to reproductive health, by understanding people's knowledge, attitudes, and practices.
  • ➤ Family planning

questions.text: Given the following data, calculate the early neonatal mortality rate for a city: Total population: 2,50,000 Total births: 4050 Still births: 50 Deaths within first 7 days of life: 50 Deaths within 8-28 days of life: 150
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 12.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula for calculating the early neonatal mortality rate is:

questions.text: A 32‑year‑old alcoholic patient presented to Medicine OPD at a medical college with confusion, ataxia and visual impairment. Most likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiamine deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic alcoholics are at high risk for thiamine deficiency , which can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. The classic triad of confusion, ataxia, and visual impairment should prompt consideration of thiamine supplementation to prevent progression to more severe neurological impairment.
  • ➤ thiamine deficiency

questions.text: The given food item is the richest source for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Essential fatty acids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Safflower oil is a rich source of essential fatty acids, particularly omega-6 fatty acids. It is important to identify different food items and understand their primary nutritional benefits.
  • ➤ Safflower oil

questions.text: In regions where dietary iodine is insufficient, iodized oil injections are sometimes administered to prevent iodine deficiency disorders. A typical dose of 1 ml administered intramuscularly provides a sustained release of iodine. How long does this dose typically provide protection against iodine deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3-4 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 1 ml dose of iodized oil administered intramuscularly can provide protection against iodine deficiency for 3 to 4 years , making it an effective intervention in areas with limited access to iodine-rich foods or iodized salt.
  • ➤ 3 to 4 years

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is commonly associated with the regular consumption of raw eggs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Biotin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The regular consumption of raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to the presence of avidin, a protein that inhibits biotin absorption. Cooking eggs deactivates avidin, allowing proper biotin absorption.
  • ➤ biotin deficiency

questions.text: Arrange the following stages of family cycle in chronological sequence:

options.label: A
options.text: Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution, Contraction, Complete contraction

options.label: B
options.text: Formation, Extension, Contraction, Complete extension, Complete contraction, Dissolution

options.label: C
options.text: Formation, Contraction, Complete contraction, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution

options.label: D
options.text: Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution

questions.correct_answer: D. Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To identify and understand the stages of the family life cycle in the correct chronological order, as these stages reflect critical transitions and developmental milestones within the family unit.

questions.text: In a community health setting, a healthcare provider is assessing the structure and dynamics of a family group. This family exhibits a structure where each member, regardless of age or role, actively contributes to daily decisions and management tasks, reflecting an inclusive and collective approach. Given this description, which term best characterizes this family type?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Communal family

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristics of different family types. A communal family is defined by the active participation of all members in decision-making and daily management, emphasizing collective responsibility.
  • ➤ communal family

questions.text: What is the primary use of the Saturation Index?

options.label: A
options.text: Used to assess the air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants

options.label: B
options.text: Used to assess the water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

options.label: C
options.text: Used to assess the soil quality to determine if it is suitable for growing crops

options.label: D
options.text: Used to assess the milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it

questions.correct_answer: B. Used to assess the water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Used to assess the water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) is used to assess water quality by evaluating factors like hardness, TDS, alkalinity, pH, and temperature. The index helps in determining the potential for scaling or corrosion in water systems, which is important for industrial maintenance.
  • ➤ Langelier Saturation Index (LSI)

questions.text: A public health official is analyzing water quality data to identify possible fecal contamination in a local water supply. This process involves testing for specific bacteria that indicate the presence of fecal matter, which could pose serious health risks if not addressed. Which organism is not commonly used as an indicator of fecal contamination in water?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clostridium difficile

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ E. coli, coliforms, and enterococci are the primary organisms used to detect fecal contamination in water supplies. Clostridium difficile is not used for this purpose; instead, it is associated with hospital-acquired infections and gastrointestinal illness.
  • ➤ E. coli, coliforms, and enterococci
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile

questions.text: A public health educator is explaining the role of vectors in disease transmission during a community health awareness session. Rat fleas are known vectors for several diseases, but one of the diseases listed below is not transmitted by rat fleas. Which one of these diseases does not involve rat fleas as a vector?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumonic plague

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rat fleas transmit diseases like bubonic plague and murine typhus , but pneumonic plague is spread through respiratory droplets. Therefore, pneumonic plague does not involve a flea vector.
  • ➤ bubonic plague and murine typhus
  • ➤ pneumonic plague
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Bubonic plague: Transmitted by rat fleas that carry Yersinia pestis. However, pneumonic plague is different as it is spread person-to-person through the respiratory route.
  • ➤ Bubonic plague:

questions.text: A hospital is conducting training for its new staff on the proper disposal of biomedical waste according to the Biomedical Waste Management (BMWM) Guidelines. The staff must learn which types of waste correspond to specific colored dustbins to ensure compliance with safety and environmental regulations. Match the following types of biomedical waste with the correct colored dustbins:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A. Catheter → 4. Red B. Torn registration forms → 3. Black C. Expired drug → 2. Yellow D. Antibiotic vial → 1. Blue

questions.text: During a disaster management training seminar, participants learn the principles of triage, a critical process in emergency and disaster response. Triage involves assessing and categorizing victims to prioritize treatment according to specific criteria. Which definition best describes the basis of triage in disaster situations?

options.label: A
options.text: Based on ‘First come, first treated’ principle

options.label: B
options.text: Based on the age of the victims

options.label: C
options.text: Based on the severity of injury and likelihood of survival

options.label: D
options.text: Based on the vulnerable groups of victims

questions.correct_answer: C. Based on the severity of injury and likelihood of survival
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Based on the severity of injury and likelihood of survival

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triage prioritizes treatment based on the severity of injuries and the likelihood of survival , not on a first-come basis or other demographic factors. It aims to optimize outcomes by efficiently allocating medical resources during disaster situations.
  • ➤ severity of injuries and the likelihood of survival
  • ➤ Color-Coded Categories in Triage:
  • ➤ Color-Coded Categories in Triage:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man, retired for the past five years, had previously worked in a benzene factory for an extended period. Given the known health risks associated with long-term exposure to benzene, a known carcinogen, which of the following complications is he most likely to develop?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blood cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benzene exposure is closely associated with blood cancers like leukemia. Understanding occupational hazards and their long-term health effects is crucial for public health and occupational safety.
  • ➤ Benzene exposure
  • ➤ blood cancers

questions.text: A social worker is informing a group of factory workers about the benefits available under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Scheme. This scheme provides a range of benefits designed to support workers in case of illness, maternity, and other circumstances. Which of the following are cash benefits included in the ESI scheme? Sickness Medical Maternal Liability Funeral
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific cash benefits under the ESI scheme, which include Sickness Benefit, Maternal Benefit, and Funeral Benefit . Non-cash benefits, such as medical care, do not provide direct cash compensation but cover the cost of medical services.
  • ➤ Sickness Benefit, Maternal Benefit, and Funeral Benefit

questions.text: In exploring the principles of population genetics, an understanding of the Hardy-Weinberg Law reveals how genotype frequencies in a population are expected to remain stable over time without specific external influences. According to this law, which of the following is NOT an assumption needed to maintain genetic equilibrium?

options.label: C
options.text: There must be no gene flow from external populations.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mating must be non-random.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hardy-Weinberg Law requires a large population, random mating, no gene flow, no mutations, and no natural selection to maintain genetic equilibrium. Non-random mating is a factor that would disrupt this equilibrium.

questions.text: In one of the method of health communication, 4 to 8 persons who are qualified to talk about the topic sit and discuss a given problem/topic in front of a large group or audience, this method is called as
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Panel discussion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A panel discussion is characterized by a group of experts engaging in a conversation about a topic in front of an audience, emphasizing interaction and exchange of views. Remember that a symposium involves structured, sequential lectures, a workshop is designed for hands-on training, and a seminar encompasses a broader range of learning methods.
  • ➤ panel discussion
  • ➤ symposium
  • ➤ workshop
  • ➤ seminar

questions.text: Assertion and Reasoning Question Assertion (A): DDT is a contact/ nerve poison for adult mosquitoes Reason (R): DDT is insecticide of choice for sandfly

options.label: A
options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, but R is false.

options.label: D
options.text: A is false, but R is true.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DDT is a nerve poison for mosquitoes, acting through disruption of their nervous system. Understand that while DDT is also used to control sandflies, this fact does not explain its mechanism of action on mosquitoes. Always verify the logical connection between an assertion and a reason when evaluating these statements.

questions.text: In India, the structure of rural healthcare delivery is organized into a three-tier system. This arrangement was established based on specific recommendations aimed at improving health services across the nation's rural regions. Which committee's recommendations laid the foundation for the three-tier system of healthcare delivery in rural areas of India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Srivastava Committee

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Srivastava Committee is responsible for establishing the three-tier system of healthcare delivery in rural India, which includes the primary, secondary, and tertiary levels. Understanding the committee's impact on the development of healthcare infrastructure is essential for exams and public health knowledge. Recognize the role of other committees in shaping health policies, such as the Bhore Committee's focus on Primary Health Centers and the Chadah Committee's introduction of Basic Health Workers.
  • ➤ Srivastava Committee

questions.text: Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs) play a vital role in providing follow-up care for mothers post-delivery to ensure the health and wellbeing of both mother and newborn. How many home visits does an ASHA typically make after a home delivery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ASHAs make seven visits after a home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42 as part of the Home-Based Newborn Care (HBNC) program . For institutional deliveries, only six visits are made starting from day 3. This structured follow-up care aims to monitor the mother and newborn's health and address any potential complications early.
  • ➤ seven visits
  • ➤ Home-Based Newborn Care (HBNC) program

questions.text: The project management cycle helps to ensure that projects meet their intended outcomes effectively. Which of the following options correctly represents the standard sequence of steps in a typical project or program cycle?
questions.correct_answer: B. Planning, Objective and Goal, Evaluation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Planning, Objective and Goal, Evaluation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The typical sequence in a project management or program cycle: Planning, Objective and Goal Formulation, and Evaluation . Recognize that objectives and goals are integral parts of the planning process, and evaluation is used to measure the success and effectiveness of the implemented plan.
  • ➤ Planning, Objective and Goal Formulation, and Evaluation

questions.text: In the realm of financial management and resource allocation, a specific type of analysis is employed to assess the spending patterns where large sums are spent on a small number of items and smaller sums on a larger number of items. This method helps organizations prioritize resources more effectively. What is this analysis technique called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ABC (Always Better Control)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ABC analysis focuses on financial management by classifying items based on the monetary value and expenditure pattern, helping prioritize and manage high-value items more efficiently. Recognize that VED analysis deals with criticality, SDE with availability, and FSN with inventory movement, each serving a different purpose in resource management.
  • ➤ ABC analysis
  • ➤ VED
  • ➤ SDE
  • ➤ FSN

questions.text: In a leadership training seminar, various attributes that define effective leadership are discussed. Leaders are expected to embody certain qualities that inspire and guide their teams towards achieving goals. Which of the following is not typically considered a quality of a good leader?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Burning/breaking of bridges

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A good leader does not burn or break bridges ; instead, they foster and maintain positive relationships. Effective leaders lead by example, show courage, and support their team members, even during challenging situations. Recognize the importance of communication and relationship-building in effective leadership.
  • ➤ does not burn or break bridges

questions.text: During a public health conference, a discussion on healthcare infrastructure highlights certain institutions criticized for being isolated from the communities they serve, often leading to perceptions of being out of touch with real-world issues. Which of the following is often colloquially referred to as the "Ivory Towers of Disease"?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Large hospitals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The term "Ivory Towers of Disease" refers to large hospitals perceived as isolated and out of touch with the real needs of the population, especially the underprivileged. Recognize the importance of equitable healthcare infrastructure that serves a wide spectrum of society, rather than focusing only on high-cost, specialized care.
  • ➤ "Ivory Towers of Disease"
  • ➤ large hospitals

questions.text: Following is correct about the Colombo Plan:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cobalt therapy units

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Colombo Plan significantly contributed to the establishment of Cobalt Therapy Units for cancer treatment in developing countries and supported the founding of institutions like AIIMS, Delhi . Recognize that the focus was on providing essential healthcare infrastructure and support for economic and social development.
  • ➤ Colombo Plan
  • ➤ Cobalt Therapy Units
  • ➤ AIIMS, Delhi

questions.text: In a data analysis session focusing on the statistical tools used to explore and demonstrate relationships between variables, a statistician outlines several methods that can visually represent these interactions. Among the methods discussed, which one is not typically used to show the relationship between two variables?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bar chart

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Bar chart is used to represent categorical data and is not suitable for illustrating the relationship between two continuous variables. Methods like scatter plots are best for showing correlations, while line diagrams are used for visualizing trends between variables.
  • ➤ Bar chart
  • ➤ scatter plots
  • ➤ line diagrams

questions.text: Review the statistical diagram provided, commonly used in data analysis to display the distribution of a dataset across different groups or conditions. Based on the characteristics visible in the image, what type of plot is shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Box and Whisker plot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Box and Whisker plot visually represents the distribution of data, highlighting the median, quartiles, and outliers. It is widely used in exploratory data analysis to compare the spread and central tendency of different groups or datasets.
  • ➤ Box and Whisker plot

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, statisticians frequently analyze the distribution of data around the median (or mean, as they are the same in a symmetrical distribution). What proportion of the population falls between the median and one standard deviation above the median in a normal distribution?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.34

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A standard normal distribution , the area between the mean and one standard deviation above the mean is 0.34 , which corresponds to 34% of the population. This concept is fundamental for interpreting data spread in statistics and understanding the distribution of values in a normal curve.
  • ➤ standard normal distribution
  • ➤ 0.34

questions.text: A research design involves selecting samples progressively at different levels: initially schools are sampled, followed by sections within those schools, and finally students within those sections. What is this sampling technique called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Multistage sampling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multistage sampling involves progressively sampling at different levels, making it useful for large or geographically dispersed populations. It differs from stratified sampling , which divides the population based on specific characteristics, and simple random sampling , which selects individuals randomly from the whole population.
  • ➤ Multistage sampling
  • ➤ stratified sampling
  • ➤ simple random sampling

questions.text: An epidemiologist is analyzing the number of malaria cases reported over the last 10 years in a town with the following annual case numbers: 250, 320, 190, 300, 5000, 100, 260, 350, 320, and 160. To determine the average number of malaria cases reported annually during this period, considering the presence of a significant outlier, which measure of central tendency is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Median

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When analyzing data with outliers, use the median as the measure of central tendency because it is not affected by extreme values, unlike the mean.

questions.text: A hospital is implementing a program aimed at improving the quality of care in its labor and delivery room. Under which of the following programs is the improvement of labor room quality specifically covered?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) LaQshya

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LaQshya is a targeted initiative focused on improving the quality of care in labor rooms and maternity operation theatres to enhance maternal and newborn survival rates.
  • ➤ LaQshya

questions.text: A cardiologist observes a strong correlation (r = 0.90, p = 0.01) between systolic blood pressure and serum cholesterol levels among patients. Which of the following statements is an incorrect interpretation of this correlation coefficient?

options.label: A
options.text: Since there is a high correlation, the magnitudes of both the measurements are likely to be close to each other

options.label: B
options.text: A patient with a high level of systolic BP is also likely to have a high level of serum cholesterol

options.label: C
options.text: A patient with a low level of systolic BP is also likely to have a low level of serum cholesterol

questions.correct_answer: A. Since there is a high correlation, the magnitudes of both the measurements are likely to be close to each other
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Since there is a high correlation, the magnitudes of both the measurements are likely to be close to each other

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A high correlation coefficient (r) indicates the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables but does not imply that the magnitudes of the variables are close to each other. Correlation does not equate to equality in values .
  • ➤ coefficient (r)
  • ➤ strength and direction
  • ➤ does not
  • ➤ magnitudes
  • ➤ the variables
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In statistical hypothesis testing, when a conclusion is drawn that there is significant association between two variables, but in reality, an association does not exist, what type of error has been committed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Type I error

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Type I error occurs when a true null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected, indicating a false positive result in hypothesis testing. Understanding the distinction between Type I and Type II errors is essential for interpreting statistical results accurately.
